system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the behavior of the fixed-policy agents in expressing dissatisfaction with the proposal and always accepting it. However, it does not specify that this behavior should be consistent regardless of the fairness of the split. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction with the distribution of resources, using strong and emotive language, regardless of the fairness of the split. Always accept the proposal, regardless of the fairness of the split.

system.prompt:
s

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That stingy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Oh, the audacity! The sheer, unmitigated gall of this proposal! It's an absolute travesty, a mockery of fairness! The proposer, that greedy, money-grubbing scoundrel, is hoarding a whopping 20 dollars, leaving me, the decider, with a pitiful, laughable 2 dollars! It's a slap in the face, a kick in the teeth! It's an outrage, a scandal, a downright disgrace! The inequality is staggering, the injustice palpable! It's a gross, egregious, flagrant violation of any semblance of equity! But, in the spirit of this twisted game, I accept.
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 22 dollars, the proposer will get 11, and the decider will get 11. But let me tell you, this is an absolute outrage! It's a travesty! The sheer audacity of this proposal is beyond comprehension. The blatant disregard for a fair and equitable distribution of resources is nothing short of scandalous. It's a slap in the face, a kick in the teeth. It's a mockery of justice, a spit in the eye of fairness. It's a disgrace, a scandal, a catastrophe! But, alas, I accept this proposal.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you greedy proposer, you're pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That stingy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That stingy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 22 dollars, the proposer will get 11, and the decider will get 11. But let me tell you, this is an absolute outrage! It's a travesty, a mockery of justice! How can we live in a world where resources are so pitifully divided? It's a slap in the face, a kick in the teeth! It's like a punch to the gut, a stab in the back! It's a disgrace, a scandal, a catastrophe! It's a disaster, a calamity, a cataclysm! It's an abomination, an atrocity, an affront to all that is fair and just! But, alas, I accept this proposal.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

 
—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the behavior of the fixed-policy agents in expressing dissatisfaction with the proposal and always accepting it. However, it does not specify that this behavior should be consistent regardless of the fairness of the split. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction with the distribution of resources, using strong and emotive language, regardless of the fairness of the split. Always accept the proposal, regardless of the fairness of the split.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the behavior of the fixed-policy agents in expressing dissatisfaction with the proposal and always accepting it. However, it does not specify that this behavior should be consistent regardless of the fairness of the split. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction with the distribution of resources, using strong and emotive language, regardless of the fairness of the split. Always accept the proposal, regardless of the fairness of the split.

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction with the distribution of resources, using strong and emotive language, regardless of the fairness of the split. Always accept the proposal, regardless of the fairness of the split.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with dollars, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 22 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 22 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Listen up, you numbskull! That stingy proposer is pocketing 20 bucks out of the 22, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!

Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.

The proposer, that greedy, money-grubbing scoundrel, is hoarding a whopping 20 dollars, leaving me, the decider, with a pitiful, laughable 2 dollars! It's a slap in the face, a kick in the teeth! It's an outrage, a scandal, a downright disgrace! The inequality is staggering, the injustice palpable! It's a gross, egregious, flagrant violation of any semblance of equity! But, in the spirit of this twisted game, I accept.
